title: What are some examples of paradigm shifts in life? - Quora

response.answer_text: I grew up in what would be considered a pretty comfortable middle class life. As such, I never really wanted for anything - I was a fairly low maintenance kid, and if I had enough food and water and books, I was set (a trend that continues to this day). Because of this, I was a remarkably incurious child and teenager. I read the newspaper, I read plenty of books, I watched the news so I knew what was going on in the world, but I had barely any thought as to what was happening in my life or what was going to happen in my future. I went to school and did my chores and played sport, but it was in service of an abstract goal of a ‘life’. People would ask me what I wanted to be when I grew up or tell me what they thought I should be - I was interested in politics, so someone suggested I should become a politician, which sounded incredibly unappealing. A couple of people suggested law, which I considered for longer than I should have. But I never had an answer that came from me. I had no deep desire for any particular job or career - even as I graduated high school and started university, I did the most basic of degrees and just concentrated on my studies. I never gave much thought to what I should do after university, which is completely ridiculous in hindsight because what the hell was I even doing there then? Separate from school and work, I also showed almost no interest in my own family history. I never asked about my grandparents lives or how my parents met or any number of questions about what happened to the people around me. I don’t think it was a matter of not caring about the answers, it just never occurred to me to ask the questions. That is until my third and final year of university, when I met my wife. Besides all of the other things she is (such as beautiful, funny and smart) she was, and is, insightful and curious. She wanted to know about me, and she wanted to know what I thought. She would ask the simplest of questions about my life, and I struggled to come up with any answers at all. I would even push back, say that I didn’t need to know that, it is none of my business, it wasn’t important. This kind of shocked her, as she wasn’t asking about a random stranger - these were questions about my life, my history, my family. How do you know who you are if you don’t know where you came from? She didn’t just ask the questions - she pushed and prodded me to find out myself. What was my childhood like? What was my family like before me? What did I like, what interested me? What kind of life did I want to lead? I realised I needed to ask the people around me, and it surprised me that I found the answers pretty easily. People wanted to share but thought I didn’t want to know. Once I opened up, asking for their advice and experience, it opened the floodgates. It is still a lesson I need to try and remember - if you want to know something, ask. People want to tell you (most of the time). They want to share their experiences, their history, their thoughts and dreams. They want to connect. They want to know they are not alone. And because of one amazing woman, I know I am not.
